thread.title: UMD Will Retire Resch's No. 1 Uniform
thread.title_full: UMD Will Retire Resch's No. 1 Uniform

title: UMD Will Retire Resch's No. 1 Uniform
text:
UMD Will Retire Resch's No. 1 Uniform 
By Zach Schneider UMD Will Retire Resch's No. 1 Uniform September 30, 2015 Updated Sep 30, 2015 at 4:21 PM CDT 
Duluth, MN (NNCNOW.com) --- Glenn "Chico" Resch will become the fourth male athlete, in any sport, to have his uniform retired by the University of Minnesota Duluth when his No. 1 jersey is raised to the rafters at AMSOIL Arena on Oct. 30, the school announced on Wednesday. 
Resch played for the UMD men's hockey team from 1968-71, becoming a staple as the Bulldogs' starting goaltender in those three seasons. 
Click here to subscribe to our daily newsletter. 
He left the program with an overall record of (28-45-2) with a 4.35 goals against average and an .876 save percentage. 
"The world for me changed during my time at UMD," said Resch, who now makes his home in Emily, Minn. "It was a launching point for me -- both personally and professionally. I met my wife (Diane) there and everything I was able to accomplish after that in hockey and in broadcasting I owe to those four years." 
Resch went on to spend 14 years in the NHL with the New York Islanders (1973-81), Colorado Rockies (1981-82), New Jersey Devils (1982-86), and Philadelphia Flyers (1986) before retiring in 1986 at the age of 37. 
He later returned to the UMD program as a television color commentator on the KBJR-TV broadcasts from 1987-90, after which he became the lead analyst in 1996 for the New Jersey Devils on MSG+ and FS-New York. 
Resch was one of 12 individuals inducted into the UMD Athletic Hall of Fame as part of the inaugural class in 1991.
